lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/eureka.eureka.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run eureka.eureka.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

* Utility class for converting date-time strings into {@link LocalDateTime} objects.
* The expected format is {@code yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm}, for example:
* If the string cannot be parsed, an {@link IllegalArgumentException} is thrown.
* Converts a date-time string into a {@link LocalDateTime} object using the format
* @param timeToBeConverted the date-time string to be converted (must not be null)
* @throws IllegalArgumentException if the string cannot be parsed
"Invalid date format. Please use yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm, e.g. 2025-09-01 18:00"
* Represents a custom dialog box consisting of a text label and an image.
* The dialog box is used in the GUI to display conversations between the user
* and the chatbot (Eureka). It can be flipped to distinguish between the user
* Creates a {@code DialogBox} with the specified text and image.
* Loads the FXML layout for the dialog box and sets the message text
* @param text the message text to display
* Flips the dialog box layout such that the {@link ImageView} is on the left
* and the text is on the right. This is typically used for Eureka's responses.
* Factory method to create a dialog box for user messages.
* @return a {@code DialogBox} representing the user's message
public static DialogBox getUserDialog(String text, Image img) {
* Factory method to create a dialog box for Eureka's messages.
* The dialog box is flipped so that the image appears on the left side.
public static DialogBox getEurekaDialog(String text, Image img) {
* The main entry point of the Eureka chatbot application.
* The {@code Eureka} class initializes the core components:
* {@link TaskList} for managing tasks, {@link Storage} for file persistence,
* and {@link Ui} for user interaction. It handles the program flow by reading
* user commands, parsing them into {@link Command} objects, executing them,
* Constructs a new {@code Eureka} instance with the given file path.
* Loads existing tasks from storage if available, otherwise starts
* @param filePath the path to the file used for task storage
* Displays a welcome message, repeatedly reads user input,
* parses it into a {@link Command}, executes it, and stops
* when an exit command is issued.
* Returns a placeholder response for GUI integration.
* The main entry point of the program.
* A launcher class for the Eureka application.
* This class exists as a workaround for JavaFX classpath issues.
* Instead of running {@link Main} directly, the program starts
* from this class, which then launches the JavaFX application.
* The main entry point of the program.
* to start the JavaFX application defined in {@link Main}.
* @param args command-line arguments passed to the application
* The entry point for the Eureka GUI application using JavaFX and FXML.
* This class sets up the primary stage, loads the FXML layout,
* and connects the UI with the {@link Eureka} backend.
* Loads the {@code MainWindow.fxml} layout, sets up the scene,
* and injects the {@link Eureka} instance into the controller.
* @param stage the primary stage provided by the JavaFX runtime
* Controller for the main Eureka GUI window defined in {@code MainWindow.fxml}.
* This class manages user interactions with the GUI:

*
  • Handles user text input from the input field

*
  • Displays user and Eureka dialog messages in the dialog container

*
  • Delegates command processing to the {@link Eureka} backend

*
  • Closes the application when an exit command is issued
* Binds the scroll pane to automatically scroll to the bottom
* whenever new dialog boxes are added to the container.
* Injects the {@link Eureka} instance into this controller.
* This is called by {@link Main} after loading the FXML.
* @param d the {@code Eureka} instance to connect with the UI
* Handles user input from the text field when the send button is clicked
* or the Enter key is pressed.

*
  • Execute the command via the {@link Eureka} backend

*
  • Display both the user's message and Eureka's response in dialog boxes

*
  • Exit the application if the command is an exit command
* If the input is invalid, an error message is displayed instead of a normal response.
* Parses raw user input strings into executable {@link Command} objects.

*
  • mark <index> – marks the 1-based task at {@code index} as done

*
  • unmark <index> – marks the 1-based task at {@code index} as not done

*
  • event <task name> /from "yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm" /to "yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm" – adds an event
* Invalid or malformed inputs result in an {@link InvalidCommand}.
* Parses a full command line into a concrete {@link Command}.
* This method performs simple prefix checks for each command and,
* where applicable, uses regular expressions to extract arguments.
* It also validates date/time strings via {@link DateTimeConverter}.
* @param fullCommand the raw user input line (e.g., {@code "deadline homework /by 2025-09-01 18:00"})
* @return a {@link Command} instance corresponding to the input; never {@code null}.
*         Returns {@link InvalidCommand} for unknown or malformed commands.
System.out.println("Invalid todo format. Task Name cannot be empty. Eg: todo homework");
System.out.println("Invalid event format. Eg: event orientation /from \"yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm\" /to \"yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm\"");
System.out.println("Invalid deadline format. Eg: deadline homework /by \"yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm\"");
* Handles reading from and writing to the storage file for tasks.
* The {@code Storage} class manages persistence by saving tasks to a text file
* and loading them back into memory when the application starts.
* Each task is stored in a serialized format and deserialized using
* Constructs a {@code Storage} instance with the given file path.
* @param filePath the path to the file where tasks will be saved/loaded
* Loads tasks from the storage file into memory.
* If the file does not exist, it will be created (along with
* the parent directory if necessary). Each non-empty line in the
* file is parsed into a {@link Task} using {@link Task#parse(String)}.
* Malformed lines are skipped with an error message.
* @return an {@link ArrayList} containing the tasks loaded from the file
* Updates the storage file with the current task list.
* Each task is written in its serialized form (via {@link Task#serialise()}),
* with one task per line. Overwrites the existing file content.
public Deadline(LocalDateTime due, String taskName, boolean isDone) {
public Event(LocalDateTime start, LocalDateTime end, String taskName, boolean isDone) {
String[] parts = line.split("\\s*\\|\\s*"); // split according to |
return new Event(LocalDateTime.parse(parts[3]), LocalDateTime.parse(parts[4]), taskName, isDone);
DateTimeFormatter custom1 = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("EEEE, MMMM dd yyyy HH:mm");
* Represents an abstract command that can be executed by the application.
* Each command defines specific behavior (e.g., add, delete, find tasks)
* and interacts with the {@link TaskList}, {@link Ui}, and {@link Storage}.
* Subclasses must implement how the command executes and whether it
* Executes the command with the given task list, user interface, and storage.
* @param tasks   the task list to operate on
* @param ui      the user interface used to display messages
* @param storage the storage used for saving/loading tasks
* @return a string response representing the command result,
public abstract String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage);
* Determines whether this command signals the application to exit.
* @return true if this command will terminate the program, false otherwise
* Represents a command that adds a {@link Deadline} task to the task list.
* A deadline task includes a description and a specific due date/time.
* When executed, the command updates the task list, saves it to storage,
* and notifies the user via the UI.
* Constructs a DeadlineCommand with the specified task name and deadline.
* @param taskName the description of the deadline task
* @param by       the due date and time of the task
* Executes the command by creating a new {@link Deadline} task,
* adding it to the {@link TaskList}, saving it to {@link Storage},
* and showing a confirmation message in the {@link Ui}.
* @param tasks   the task list to add the new deadline task into
* @param ui      the user interface used to display feedback
* @param storage the storage used to persist the updated task list
* @return a confirmation message containing the details of the added task
*         and the updated number of tasks
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
assert tasks.getTask(totalTasks - 1) != null : "last task should exist";
return "Got it. I've added this task:\n"
* Indicates whether this command will terminate the program.
* @return false, since adding a deadline task does not exit the program
* Represents a command that deletes a task from the {@link TaskList}.
* The task is identified by its index in the list. If the index is valid,
* the task is removed, the storage is updated, and the user is notified
* Constructs a DeleteCommand with the specified task index.
* @param index the zero-based index of the task to delete
* Executes the delete command by removing the task at the given index
* from the {@link TaskList}, updating {@link Storage}, and showing
* @param tasks   the task list from which the task will be deleted
* @param ui      the user interface used to show messages
* @param storage the storage used to persist changes after deletion
* @return a confirmation message showing the deleted task and updated count,
*         or an error message if the index is invalid
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
System.out.println("Now you have " + tasks.getCount() + " tasks in the list.");
* Indicates whether this command will terminate the program.
* @return false, since deleting a task does not exit the program
* Represents a command that adds an {@link Event} task to the {@link TaskList}.
* An event task includes a description and a time range (start and end).
* When executed, the command updates the task list, saves it to storage,
* and notifies the user through the {@link Ui}.
* Constructs an EventCommand with the specified task name and event duration.
* @param taskName the description of the event
* @param from     the starting date and time of the event
* @param to       the ending date and time of the event
public EventCommand(String taskName, LocalDateTime from, LocalDateTime to) {

* This method is primarily used for testing.
* @return the start {@link LocalDateTime} of the event
* Executes the event command by creating a new {@link Event} task,
* adding it to the {@link TaskList}, saving it to {@link Storage},
* and displaying a confirmation message through the {@link Ui}.

* @param ui      the user interface used to show messages
* @param storage the storage used to persist the updated task list
* @return a confirmation message containing the added event
*         and the updated number of tasks
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
assert tasks.getTask(totalTasks - 1) != null : "last task should exist";
return "Got it. I've added this task:\n"
* Indicates whether this command will terminate the program.
* @return false, since adding an event does not exit the program
* Represents a command that exits the application.
* When executed, this command shows a farewell message
* through the {@link Ui} and signals the program to terminate.
* Executes the exit command by displaying a farewell message.
* @param tasks   the task list (not used in this command)
* @param ui      the user interface used to show the farewell message
* @param storage the storage (not used in this command)
* @return a simple "Bye" message for GUI display
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
* Indicates that this command will terminate the program.
* @return true, since this command exits the application
* Represents a command that searches for tasks in the task list
* The command checks all tasks in the {@link TaskList} and returns
* a formatted list of matching tasks. If no matches are found,
* Constructs a FindCommand with the specified keyword to search for.
* @param keyword the keyword to search for in the task list
* Executes the find command by searching the given {@link TaskList}
* for tasks that contain the keyword. Displays results to the UI
* and returns a formatted string for GUI display.
* @param tasks   the task list to search in
* @param ui      the user interface used to show messages
* @param storage the storage used to save or load data (not modified here)
* @return a formatted string containing the matching tasks, or a message
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
return "No matching tasks found for keyword: " + keyword;
System.out.println("Here are the matching tasks in your list:");
sb.append("Here are the matching tasks in your list:\n");
* Indicates whether this command will terminate the program.
* @return false, as FindCommand does not exit the program
* Represents an invalid or unrecognized command entered by the user.
* When executed, this command displays and returns an error message
* indicating that the input was invalid. It does not terminate the program.
* Executes the invalid command by displaying an error message
* to the console and returning it for GUI display.
* @param tasks   the task list (not used in this command)
* @param ui      the user interface (not used in this command)
* @param storage the storage (not used in this command)
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
* Indicates whether this command will terminate the program.
* @return false, since invalid input does not exit the application
* Represents a command that lists all tasks in the {@link TaskList}.
* When executed, this command prints the tasks to the console via {@link Ui}
* and also returns a formatted string for GUI display. If the list is empty,
* Executes the list command by displaying all tasks in the {@link TaskList}.
* Also formats the tasks into a string for GUI display.
* @param tasks   the task list whose tasks are to be listed
* @param ui      the user interface used to display tasks
* @param storage the storage (not used in this command)
* @return a formatted string containing all tasks,
*         or a message indicating the list is empty
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list:");
sb.append("Here are the tasks in your list:\n");
* Indicates whether this command will terminate the program.
* @return false, since listing tasks does not exit the application
* Represents a command that marks a task as completed in the {@link TaskList}.
* The task is identified by its index. If the index is invalid, an error message
* is returned instead. When successful, the updated task is shown to the user
* Constructs a MarkCommand with the specified task index.
* @param index the zero-based index of the task to mark as done
* Returns the index of the task to be marked.
* This method is primarily intended for testing.
* @return the zero-based index of the task
* Executes the mark command by marking the specified task in the {@link TaskList}
* as completed, updating {@link Storage}, and displaying feedback via {@link Ui}.
* @param tasks   the task list containing the task to be marked
* @param ui      the user interface used to show messages
* @param storage the storage used to persist the updated task list
* @return a confirmation message showing the marked task,
*         or an error message if the index is invalid
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
System.out.println("Nice! I've marked this task as done:");
return "Nice! I've marked this task as done:\n"
* Indicates whether this command will terminate the program.
* @return false, since marking a task does not exit the application
* Represents a command that adds a {@link Todo} task to the {@link TaskList}.
* A todo task contains only a description, without any specific date or time.
* When executed, this command updates the task list, saves it to storage,
* and notifies the user through the {@link Ui}.
* Constructs a TodoCommand with the specified task name.
* @param taskName the description of the todo task
* Executes the todo command by creating a new {@link Todo} task,
* adding it to the {@link TaskList}, saving it to {@link Storage},
* and displaying a confirmation message through the {@link Ui}.
* @param tasks   the task list to which the todo will be added
* @param ui      the user interface used to display messages
* @param storage the storage used to persist the updated task list
* @return a confirmation message containing the added todo
*         and the updated number of tasks
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
assert tasks.getTask(totalTasks - 1) != null : "last task should exist";
return "Got it. I've added this task:\n"
* Indicates whether this command will terminate the program.
* @return false, since adding a todo does not exit the application
* Represents a command that marks a task as not completed in the {@link TaskList}.
* The task is identified by its index. If the index is invalid, an error message
* is returned instead. When successful, the updated task is shown to the user
* Constructs an UnmarkCommand with the specified task index.
* @param index the zero-based index of the task to mark as not done
* Executes the unmark command by marking the specified task in the {@link TaskList}
* as not completed, updating {@link Storage}, and displaying feedback via {@link Ui}.
* @param tasks   the task list containing the task to be unmarked
* @param ui      the user interface used to show messages
* @param storage the storage used to persist the updated task list
* @return a confirmation message showing the unmarked task,
*         or an error message if the index is invalid
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
System.out.println("OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:");
return "OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:\n"
* Indicates whether this command will terminate the program.
* @return false, since unmarking a task does not exit the application
* Handles interactions between the user and the application.
* The {@code Ui} class is responsible for displaying messages,
* reading user input, and formatting output to the console.
* It provides feedback for actions such as loading errors,
* adding tasks, showing task lists, and exiting the program.
* Displays an error message when task history cannot be loaded.
System.out.println("There is an error loading the tasks history.");
* Displays a horizontal line divider for formatting.
* Displays the welcome message when the program starts.
System.out.println("What can I do for you?");
* Displays an error message to the user.
* @param error the error message to display
* Reads a command from user input.
* @return the command string entered by the user
* Displays the farewell message when the program exits.
System.out.println("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* Displays a confirmation message after a task has been added,
* showing the most recently added task and the updated count.
* @param taskList the task list containing the newly added task
System.out.println("Got it. I've added this task:");
System.out.println("Now you have " + taskList.getCount() + " tasks in the list.");

<AnchorPane maxHeight="-Infinity" maxWidth="-Infinity" minHeight="-Infinity" minWidth="-Infinity" prefHeight="600.0" prefWidth="400.0" stylesheets="@../css/main.css" xmlns="http://javafx.com/javafx/17" xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml/1" fx:controller="eureka.MainWindow">
